> - Another issue, I think it's better to divide those 120 cases into

This is very deep point. When you write your tests with parametrized
method, that is when your test your class with different inputs, you
should divide your input in to EQUIVALENCE CLASSES.
Let me explain this in more simple example. Suppose, you want to check
Math.sqrt(double a) methods. What values should you check? First of
all, you have to notice, that valid input is only [0, +Inf). So, all
values are spitted down at least to (-Inf, 0), [0, +Inf). This are
your equivalence class in first approximation. You should try, say -7
from (-Inf, ), +20 from [0, +Inf). You should also try value that is
in boundary of your interval, that is 0. Sometimes, it is reasonable
to test also value that are "near" boundary, for example 1 and -1. It
can be the case, that this separation is not enough. First of all,
what about special double values such as NaN? What about -Inf and
+Inf? And if you test them, perhaps it is worth to test
Double.MAX_VALUE and Double.MIN_VALUE as "nearest" values? It can be
also reasonable to test the quadratic integer numbers separately.
(Quadratic number is number that is exact square, that is a is
Quadratic number iff exist number x such that x*x=a) (Run
System.out.println(Math.pow(Math.sqrt(15), 2)); to see why this can be
important). So, your equivalence class will be (-Inf, 0), {0},
(0,1,2,4,9, 16,... all quadratic numbers}=QI, (0, +Inf)\quadratic
numbers QI, {NaN}, {-Inf}, {+Inf}.
In your case is up to your to decide how to divide to equivalence
classes. Partition to simple selection, selection with where clause
etc can be or can be not useful just as in the example with
Math.sqrt() and quadratic numbers.
